body: This seems like a bug in Selenium where args should be initialized to an empty array.  Fix would be to either use `add_argument` or `headless!` rather than shifting into the array if the Firefox::Options instance responds to the method
Thank you @twalpole .  You make Capybara the best part of the Ruby ecosystem.
@jcoyne Thanks for the kind words,  I'll try and get an updated release out this weekend

@twalpole - unfortunately this broke Selenium 3.142.7:

```
ArgumentError:
  wrong number of arguments (given 3, expected 1..2)
# ./features/build/.gems/gems/selenium-webdriver-3.142.7/lib/selenium/webdriver/common/logger.rb:12:in `deprecate'
# ./features/build/.gems/gems/capybara-3.35.1/lib/capybara/selenium/logger_suppressor.rb:12:in `deprecate'
# ./features/build/.gems/gems/selenium-webdriver-3.142.7/lib/selenium/webdriver/firefox/legacy/driver.rb:34:in `initialize'
# ./features/build/.gems/gems/selenium-webdriver-3.142.7/lib/selenium/webdriver/firefox/driver.rb:35:in `new'
# ./features/build/.gems/gems/selenium-webdriver-3.142.7/lib/selenium/webdriver/common/driver.rb:54:in `for'
# ./features/build/.gems/gems/selenium-webdriver-3.142.7/lib/selenium/webdriver.rb:88:in `for'
# ./features/build/.gems/gems/capybara-3.35.1/lib/capybara/selenium/driver.rb:83:in `browser'
# ./features/build/.gems/gems/capybara-3.35.1/lib/capybara/selenium/driver.rb:210:in `current_window_handle'
# ./features/build/.gems/gems/capybara-3.35.1/lib/capybara/session.rb:448:in `current_window'
# ./features/spec_helper.rb:97:in `block in <main>'
```

We have to go back to `3.34.0` because of that.
Umm - and it looks like you're using the legacy firefox integration? We haven't officially supported that in over a year, so I'm surprised it still works in 3.34 actually.
@boris-petrov Also, what version of Ruby are you using?
@boris-petrov Should be fixed in 3.35.3 - but it really is time to get off the legacy firefox driver and move to using the W3C compliant driver with modern firefox

@twalpole - yes, this is using the legacy Firefox integration. It still works like a charm even now so thank you for (involuntarily) supporting it! :smile: We're using JRuby.

Thanks for the quick fix - it works great! As for the legacy driver - you're right, we're using the latest Chrome for our tests but we also want to test an "old" browser on Linux - the legacy Firefox driver is the only thing that is available as a choice. If you have better ideas...?

Dont really have a suggestion for testing old browsers (other than dont) but the first Firefox browser that supported the w3c mode is pretty old now too (though it was buggy).. You would need to look at what percentage of your customers are really using and old Firefox...  I can say that Selenium 4 drops the legacy driver so youre going to be forced to update if you want to stay up to date with Selenium
